Message.Title: Samsung $4b fab investment
Message.Msg: Shifting alliances: Samsung invests $4 billion in foundry expansion By Joel Hruska on August 21, 2012 at 11:09 am1 Comment Share This Article Samsung has stated that it intends to spend $4 billion to renovate its Austin, Texas foundry in order to boost SoC production. This latest expansion is in addition to the company’s previously announced plan to build a $1.98 billion fab in South Korea. Samsung is also adding logic manufacturing capacity. If the manufacturer’s relationship with Apple were cozy, this sort of investment would be a no-brainer — Apple’s business has driven Samsung’s foundry revenue from $1.2 billion in 2010 to an estimated $3.735 billion in 2012. That jump could make Samsung the third-largest foundry in the world behind TSMC and GlobalFoundries. But, as it happens, things with Apple aren’t hunky-dory. They’re more accurately described as terrible, and consumers will ultimately end up picking up the bill for these court cases, no matter whose devices you prefer. We’ll know soon if Apple hired Samsung to fabricate the chip at the heart of the upcoming iPhone 5, but this may not matter much in the grand scheme of things. If Apple committed to manufacturing parts at Samsung as part of a long-term contract governing both SoCs and NAND flash, it may not have a choice. Samsung is caught in a paradox; its biggest foundry customer is trying to drive it out of business through legal challenges and ridiculous up-front demands (Apple wanted $30-$40 from Samsung for every device the Korean manufacturer sold). That’s neither sustainable nor desireable and it gives the company every reason on Earth to seek additional foundry customers. One of the top names on the short list is Nvidia; the two manufacturers are rumored to have paired up on Tegra 4 (T40). Whether or not NV did more than prototype the device at Samsung isn’t clear, but there’s been interest on both sides of the fence regarding a long-term strategic partnership. Samsung's current leading-edge technology is 32nm HKMG For Samsung, building relationships with other partners makes a lot of sense. Recent comments from TSMC may have driven that foundry’s customers to seek other options as well. During the company’s last earnings call, CEO Morris Chang stated that “now it makes complete sense to dedicate a whole fab to just one customer and hold that… there are customers that are getting bigger and bigger. So it makes sense that we dedicate a whole fab or even more than a whole fab to just one customer.” Chang went on to reassure nervous investors that the company remains committed to all its partners, but the short list of companies big enough to convince TSMC to dedicate an entire foundry’s worth of output to its products is short indeed. Apple has over $100 billion in the bank, craves exclusivity, and is more than willing to pay for it. That’s more than enough to make Samsung, Qualcomm, Texas Instruments, and Nvidia nervous. We don’t expect any major short-term changes, but by this time next year, Samsung will likely be talking up its new portfolio of partners, whether its still building chips for Apple or not. Between Cupertino’s courtroom antics and Chang’s fab predictions, doing anything else would be terminally short-sighted.

Topic.Title: Apple: One down, dozens to go.

Message.Msg: . . "Amazon's recent push into the smartphone and tablet market (starting with the Kindle Fire) is what really has Apple fuming. Seems like a lawsuit just waiting to happen. And Colin Gillis with BCG Financial expects it to come sooner rather than later. "When Amazon does its big event in September, is it going to be a phone?," he said of the scheduled product launch on Sept. 6 in an interview with UPI. "Because if it's a phone, they're going to be sued, probably on Sept. 7. No joke." . . . So Best? Apple can't sue Amazon for patent infringement BEFORE it's launched, right? I didn't think so. 'Cause no harm has been done before it's launched. So Apple probably has their court papers ready to go, and now they just have to wait. Imagine being a hapless parts supplier to Amazon? Knowing it's gonna get smacked down as soon as it launches. That can't be fun -- nor profitable. . . .

Message.Title: Apple iPhone 5: 50 Million + Sales Possible
Message.Msg: . . Baird: iPhone 5 ‘Poised For Lift-Off,’ 50M+ Sales Possible; Little Interest In Potential FB Phone. By Teresa Rivas | August 23, 2012, 10:30 A.M. ET. On the heels of yesterday’s survey by Piper Jaffray, today Robert W. Baird analyst William Power has his own survey out, concurring that Apple‘s (AAPL) iPhone 5, which many expect to be launched next month, will see strong demand from consumers. Power writes that of 2,000 survey respondents, 39% said they are currently eligible for an upgrade and another 6% will become so within three months. Of those upgrade-eligible respondents, 45% plan to purchase an iPhone and the vast majority are waiting for the iPhone 5. The next biggest group, 31%, said that they were undecided on their next phone, and those planning to buy Google‘s (GOOG) Android devices rounded out the bottom at 22%. Power writes “Those percentages, if they held, could suggest 50 million+ iPhone 5 sales in the U.S. alone, well above current forecasts.” Consumers viewed longer battery life, 4G/LTE, improved Siri, improved back camera and a larger screen as the most important features for them, i that order. Power also found that iPhone customers were the most loyal, with 77% of current iPhone users planning to purchase another iPhone, (18% were undecided and 5% planning to purchase an Android device). Android’s loyalty was at 48% (with 34% undecided and 17% planning to purchase an iPhone.) However, Research In Motion‘s (RIMM) customers had almost no loyalty: just 2% said they would buy a new BlackBerry. “Importantly, we would note that RIM’s base in the U.S. is likely increasingly enterprise focused, with most growth generally now overseas.” As for other possible entrants to the smartphone arena, Amazon (AMZN) substantially outdid Facebook (FB): 51% of consumers said they would be interested in the former, while only 7% expressed interest in a phone from the social network. Power concludes with a note on carriers: “Though not surprising, the high number of eligible upgrades is likely to pressure margins for the U.S. wireless carriers in Q3 and Q4, perhaps more than expected. AT&T (T) appears to have the highest exposure among the iPhone carriers, with 42% of surveyed subscribers currently eligible.” . . . "Could suggest 50 million+ iPhone 5 sales in the U.S. alone -- well above current forecasts.” That could take quite a large bite out of Android sales, right boys? And they wonder why nvidia plunges day after day after day..... . . .

Topic.Title: Where will this settle short term?

Message.Msg: Stock Consultant gives the fixed historical support/resistance points but you can't ignore the major moving averages as support/resistance points until they are broken and the 200 MA currently at 14.01 held today so that is the next nominal support until proven otherwise.

Topic.Title: NVDA very high up on WSJ "buying on Weakness" list

Message.Msg: Ibexx...I saw it, too, and it was on the last trade at 4PM...there was a block of just under 1mm shares on an uptick that was the final closing price of 14.05. With these low volume days in the last week of summer, NOTHING really matters. However, with no buyers willing to step up, and the market vulnerable to at least a short term sell off after Uncle Ben speaks, tomorrow, the shorts can do what they will until we find out the truth about whether or not AMZN picked Tegra 3 or 3+ for the new Kindle Fire Coyote and/or Hollywood. As always, we'll know in the fullness of time. Best, Max
